Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 43459-013  
Transaction Technical Assistance Facility (F-TRTA) 
October 2018 
 
 
 
 
India: Capacity Building for Project Design, 
Implementation and Evaluation 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

as of 20 September 2018

  TPRM  –  tripartite portfolio review meetings

Vice-President  Wencai Zhang, Operations 1

territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY AT A GLANCE 
I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY   
A.  Justification  1 
B.  Outputs and Activities  3 
C.  Cost and Financing  5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  5 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S  DECISION                                                                                        6                                                                                      
   
 
APPENDIXES 
1.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  7 
2.  Projects under Technical Assistance Facility  8 
3.  List of Linked Documents                                                                                                   9

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Alignment with Strategy. The transaction technical assistance facility (TA facility) will 
implement the operational focus of the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) three strategic pillars 
of Country Partnership Strategy (CPS) for India (2018–2022)1 and relevant priorities identified in 
Strategy  2030,2 to  pursue  sound  project  portfolio  performance  through  structured  capacity 
building, implementation support, and knowledge sharing. The TA facility will provide (i) demand 
driven  capacity  development  programs  on  project  design,  implementation  and  evaluation 
following government and ADB guidelines and procedures; (ii) seminars on sector and thematic 
topics; (iii) knowledge products and their sharing and cross learning sessions; and (iv) support for 
sound implementation of ongoing and pipeline projects among the central and state government 
executing and implementing agencies through tripartite portfolio review meetings (TPRM) and 
expert advice. These will ensure sound implementation performance of ongoing projects and 
project readiness and quality at entry of pipeline projects, with due attention to projects’ impact 
evaluation and lessons learned. The TA facility has been included in India’s Country Operations 
Business Plan (2018–2020).3 The purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, costs and 
financing arrangements were confirmed by the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA), Ministry 
of Finance, Government of India in September 2018. 
 
2.  Portfolio Growth and Performance. ADB’s sovereign loan portfolio in India at the 
beginning of 2018 was $14.38 billion with uncommitted amount of $3.60 billion (25%) and 
undisbursed  amount  of  $8.48  billion  (59%).  The  CPS  envisages  increasing  ADB’s  annual 
sovereign lending from the average of $2.65 billion per year in 2012–2016 to $3.00 billion, while 
aiming for annual contract award and disbursement to progressively become commensurate with 
the increased annual commitment level. It also aims at enhancing partnerships in low income 
states in northern, eastern, and north eastern regions where capacity constraint is a major issue, 
and to new areas such as economic corridors and integrated urban development having more 
complex implementation challenges. Executing agencies with little or no prior experience in 
implementing large-scale projects are expected to receive more ADB lending in the next five 
years.4   
 
3.  To  sustain  the  existing  portfolio  performance  and  expand  the  portfolio  to  new  and 
challenging geographical locations, sectors, and themes, it is crucial to build capacities and 
systems of executing agencies for designing and implementing projects with high standards. For 
ongoing projects, project performance is often affected by underdeveloped capacity of executing 
agencies  in  procurement,  consultant  recruitment,  construction  management,  contract 
administration, financial management, safeguards, gender, and monitoring and control.5 The 
projects also often encounter frequent transfers of project directors and other key project staff, 
                                                
1  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy India, 2018–2022 — Accelerating Inclusive Economic Transformation.  
https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/institutional-document/363331/cps-ind-2018-2022.pdf  
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/institutional-document/435391/strategy-2030-main-document.pdf 
3  ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan. India 2018-2020. 
https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/institutional-document/363336/cobp-ind-2018-2020.pdf. The TA first 
appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 2 April 2018. The allocation for TA facility has 
been increased from $1.5 million to $2.5 million 
4  Executing agencies of new projects from Madhya Pradesh, Sikkim, Odisha, Uttar Pradesh among others with little 
experience in implementing large projects financed by multilateral development banks would be entering the portfolio 
over the next 5 years. 
5 Issues requiring the government interdepartmental coordination such as land acquisition, resettlement, forest 
clearance, and utility shifting pose particular challenges.

2     
calling for due trainings to build and retain institutional knowledge. Low participation of good 
quality  contractors  and  consultants  in  procurement  process  and  poor  performance  during 
implementation has been another bottleneck, which need to be controlled through effective 
procurement design, performance monitoring and control mechanisms, and associated systems 
and capacities of the project agencies. These gaps can adversely affect project quality in terms 
of time, cost, and quality, and finally on its outcomes. Further, it is very important to learn from 
the implementation experience of projects and plough back the lessons learned into the design 
of  new  projects  and  implementation  of  ongoing  projects.  In  addition,  sensitizing  executing 
agencies to thematic topics would facilitate adoption of modern project management practices, 
innovative approaches, and high level technologies (HLT) among others. 
 
4.  ADB’s Engagement. ADB’s India country operations have addressed these challenges 
through Capacity Development Resource Center (CDRC) created under TA 7593-IND: Capacity 
Development for Project Implementation.6 CDRC trained about 6,000 executing agency staff 
during 2010-2017 on training topics identified through training needs assessment survey. The 
training topics included ADB policies and procedures on procurement, consultant recruitment, 
safeguards, disbursement, financial reporting and auditing, gender and social inclusion, project 
management, contract and construction management, operation and maintenance, and thematic 
topics such as new construction techniques, road safety, asset management, among others. 
Training content was finalized in consultation with executing agencies to ensure relevance for 
operations. Training programs were delivered by national institutions, as well as ADB resource 
persons, to make capacity development local resource driven and economical. These institutes 
have  included  Administrative  Staff  College  of  India  (ASCI),  Indian  Academy  of  Highway 
Engineers, Indian Society for Trenchless Technology, the Energy and Resources Institute, Indian 
Institute  of  Technology  (Roorkee),  among  others.  A  compendium  of  200  frequently  asked 
questions on contract management was compiled as ready reference tool. CDRC trainings 
received highly positive feedback from executing agencies during an impact assessment study.7 
This was also acknowledged by Country Assistance Program Evaluation 2007-2015 (CAPE)8 as 
a unique example of capacity development. TPRMs have established an institutional mechanism 
for  addressing  a  range  of  implementation  issues  from  project  design  and  start  up  toward 
successful completion and evaluation of projects. 
 
5.  The proposed TA facility aspires to consolidate and further strengthen the institutional 
approach for delivering capacity development programs and portfolio oversight through TPRMs. 
In addition, the TA facility would align the capacity building programs to the strategic framework 
of CPS 2018-22 and relevant operational priorities of Strategy 2030. The proposed TA facility 
would progressively introduce new materials and instruments, including (i) upgrading training 
materials  through  the  most  recent  case  studies;  (ii)  undertaking  advanced  training  needs 
assessment  study  to  identify  specific  capacity  gaps  of  the  selected  agencies;  (iii)  further 
documenting good  implementation  practices  as  useful reference materials for  practitioners, 
including lessons learned from projects to facilitate improved project design and implementation; 
and (iv) promoting new technologies in individual sectors by establishing catalogues from ADB’s 
knowledge networks. In terms of capacity building approach, the TA facility will prioritize field-
based trainings through clinic style issue resolution sessions as compared with classroom 
trainings,  while  promoting  cross  learning  platforms  to  support  knowledge  transfer  from 
experienced to new executing agencies. Efforts will also be made to institutionalize capacity 
                                                
6  The TA was approved in September 2010 and due for closure in December 2018. 
7  The study was published in 2016 under the title Capacity Development for Project Implementation – The Operation 
and Experience of the Capacity Development Resource Center at ADB’s India Resident Mission. 
8  ADB. 2017. Country Assistance Program Evaluation, 2007–2015.  
https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/evaluation-document/182918/files/cape-india.pdf

3 
building by helping establish pools of local trainers in partnership with the existing training 
institutes. Furthermore, the TA facility will provide critical support for sound implementation of 
ongoing projects in a selective manner during its implementation period.9  
  
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Capacity Development of Executing Agencies. The TA facility will conduct 
50 capacity building programs to train about 2,000 staff from executing and implementing 
agencies of ongoing and pipeline projects and associated central and state agencies during 2018-
2021. The topics will cover ADB policies and procedures, project implementation, Public Private 
Partnership (PPP), sector and thematic topics including cutting edge innovations for improved 
project portfolio performance, with higher emphasis on field level clinic style issue resolution 
workshops.  The  training  programs  would  be  identified  and  arranged  based  on  capacity 
assessment of executing agencies and periodic training needs surveys. The TA facility will also 
support rolling out of ADB’s Procurement Policy 2017. Thematic topics will be reflected into sector 
specific programs. ADB staff and resource persons from ADB Community of Practice (COP) will 
participate in training based on the needs to discuss international best practices. This Output also 
aims to incorporate the following features:  
 
(i)  Based  on  implementation  experience  of  earlier  TA  7593,  the  TA  facility  will 
institutionalize training subjects such as fundamentals of project management, 
contract  management,  construction  management,  and  financial  management, 
among  others  in  anchor  institutions  and  pool  of  local  experts  (including 
experienced staff from executing agencies) to make the capacity development 
activities locally driven. Anchor institutions would be supported to offer training 
programs  to  executing  agencies  of  central  and  state  government  and  other 
agencies on a chargeable basis to make this initiative sustainable.  
(ii)  Support  training  programs  covering  topics  such  as  ADB’s  project  cycle, 
procurement,  consultant  selection,  safeguards,  fund  flow,  construction 
management, contract management, DEA project readiness checklist, among 
others, and encourage new executing agencies to attend these sessions before 
loan negotiations/approval so that they are better capacitated for project design 
and implementation.  
(iii)  Enhance a training management information system (TMIS) which would improve 
training administration efficiency through web-based nominations, selection of 
participants, trainee data base, trainee tracking and training logistics management. 
TMIS will be hosted in the existing DEA website eapdea.gov.in.10  
(iv)  Pilot an advanced training needs assessment study consisting of analysis of job 
roles in the project, skill sets required for performing the job role, existing skill set, 
skill gap and strategies for filling the skill gap to provide enhanced and targeted 
capacity development support especially for those executing agencies who are in 
the lower end of the spectrum.   
                                                
9  Potential projects include Loan 3001-IND: Himachal Pradesh Clean Energy Transmission Project (Tranche 2) and 
Loan 3183-IND: Rajasthan Urban Sector Development Project and other ongoing and pipeline projects (Appendix 
2). Consultancy support on project, contract and financial management may be provided for Loan 3001 to expedite 
implementation of Tranche 2 and future tranches. In Loan 3183, the TA facility may support capacity building of 
Urban Local Bodies in operation and maintenance of assets created under the project after turnover. The TA facility 
may support other projects in India that are under preparation, implementation or evaluation, as needed. 
10 The website eapdea.gov.in is being operated and maintained by DEA and TMIS will be operated and maintained by 
DEA.

4     
(v)  Conduct six Business Opportunity Seminars (BOS) in collaboration with contractor 
and consultant organizations on a regular basis to disseminate information on 
ADB’s business opportunities while undertaking dialogues on the specific ways 
and means to further strengthen the procurement systems based on the field level 
experience and lessons.  
 
7.  Output 2: Knowledge Products Sharing and Cross Learning. Knowledge sharing and 
cross learning will be supported through the following six sub-outputs: (i) prepare publications 
covering latest technologies, construction materials and management practices for ADB financed 
sectors; 11 (ii) undertake field visits to project sites for hands-on experience on good project 
management practices and support executing agency  staff participation in national/ international 
conferences and seminars which may include field visits;  (iii) support preparing case studies, 
frequently  asked  questions  (FAQs)  and  lessons  learned  for  documentation  of  advanced 
implementation and related practices as a reference knowledge base as envisaged in CPS and 
as training material for capacity development programs; (iv) documenting lessons learned from 
projects to facilitate improved project design and implementation;  (v) support impact assessment 
of training programs and improvements in portfolio results monitoring and evaluation; and (vi) 
organize high level sector forums to facilitate cross learning among executing agencies and ADB 
staff and provide a platform for presenting national and international good project implementation 
practices as well as exemplary quality outputs. Some of the sector and thematic topics include 
the following:12 
 
(i)  Transport  sector:  Modern  technologies  in  transport  sector;  road  asset 
management system; road safety; PPPs in transport projects; contract modalities 
for execution of transport projects; financing modalities; good practices in road 
maintenance; climate change mitigation and adaptation in transport projects; 
corporatization for road sector management, among others. 
(ii)  Urban sector: Supporting livable cities through structuring of ‘24x7’ water supply 
using smart water management systems; preparation of master plans for towns 
development; solid waste management system planning; climate resilient cities; 
and sustainable urban service delivery, among others. 
(iii)  Energy sector: PPP in power distribution; variable renewable energy integration 
to power systems; use of smart meters for improving operational performance of 
DISCOMS; and feeder separation and new approaches for power distribution, 
among others. 
(iv)  Human development sector: Use of high end education technologies; generating 
quality  jobs;  leadership  program  for  managers  of  Technical  and  Vocational 
Education (TVET) institutions; designing TVET training facilities and standard 
equipment specifications; and curriculum design and development, among others. 
(v)  Agriculture  and  natural  resources  sector:  Improving  market  connectivity  and 
agricultural value chain linkages; increased agricultural productivity and rural 
incomes; modern irrigation management practices; and river basin planning, 
among others.  
(vi)  Other topics: Use of high level technologies (HLT); pursuing gender equality and 
reducing time poverty of women, among others. 
 
                                                
11 Preference would be given to distribute digital copies. 500 copies will be printed on demand and distributed to those 
Executing agency staff who stay in interior and remote areas where computers and internet facilities are not available. 
12 These topics are indicative and will be fine-tuned in consultation with sector thematic groups and sector operation 
staff during preparation of annual training calendar.

5 
8.  Output 3: Portfolio Performance Improvements. Improved performance of the portfolio 
will have 3 sub-outputs: (i) fund nine TPRMs of ongoing and pipeline projects to support improved 
portfolio  performance,  quality  and  timeliness  of  implementation  and  project  readiness;  (ii) 
strengthen a standard portfolio performance management system (PPMS) applicable to all ADB-
assisted projects to facilitate implementation progress monitoring and troubleshooting; and (iii) 
provide support to ongoing and pipeline projects in procurement, contract management, financial 
management, reporting and auditing, safeguards, gender among others, for which consultancy 
support will be provided to resolve the specifically identified implementation problems.

The DMFs of the ongoing projects will be updated, as needed, to reflect the outputs and activities of the TA facility. The 
updated versions will be in the project administration manuals.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $3,000,000, of which $2,500,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government 
will provide counterpart support in the form of domestic transportation from duty station to training 
venue city and other in-kind contributions which will constitute 20% of the total TA amount.  The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  The executing agency of the TA facility will be Department of Economic Affairs (DEA), 
Ministry  of  Finance,  the  Government  of  India.  TA  facility  activities  will  be  administered by 
ADB through the India Resident Mission. The travel cost of ADB and non-ADB resource persons 
would be met from the TA facility.13 The TA facility will facilitate training programs, workshops and 
related logistic arrangements as training services through national/international training institutes 
and  event  management  service  providers.  Training  and  event  management  services  are 
                                                
13  ADB staff will be used as resource persons on need basis.

6     
considered as non-consulting services as per paragraph 24 of the Staff Instructions for Technical 
Assistance Procurement of Goods, Works and Non-consulting Services. PPMS and TMIS will be 
hosted on DEA website eapdea.gov.in and will be maintained by DEA after TA facility completion. 
 
11.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 2.

a Procurement Plan is in List of linked documents in Appendix 3. 
 
12.  Consulting Services. In addition to this, the TA facility plans to recruit 17 individual 
national consultants for 203-person months and two individual international consultants for 3-
person months. ADB will engage individual consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.14 Indicative consultant allocation and projects under TA facility are in Appendix 
2. Some of the TA facility consultants will be engaged using framework type of contracts in 
consultation with PPFD. 
 
II   THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance facility not exceeding the equivalent of $2,500,000 on a grant 
basis to the Government of India for Capacity Building for Project Design, Implementation and 
Evaluation and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                
14  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
